choices.B: Change the IF condition in the anonymous block to CARDINALITY (1_dept) IS NULL.
choices.A: Change the IF condition in the anonymous block to 1_dept IS EMPTY.
choices.C: Add BEQUEATH DEFINER to the EMP_COUNT_VW view.
choices.F: Add AUTHID CURRENT_USER to the EMP_COUNT function.
choices.D: Add BEQUEATH CURRENT_USER to the EMP_COUNTS_VW view.
choices.E: IN BRANCH2 execute GRANT INHERIT PRIVILEGES ON USER branch2 TO branch1;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BDF
BDF ist correct
Correct: BDF

comments.content: BDF makes sense but why would you want to add BEQUEATH CURRENT_USER and AUTHID CURRENT_USER ? Both come default with DEFINER and is still good, it works.

discussion.content: NUMBER & POSITIVEN
A, B and E (A and B are identicall)
C is most certainly not one of the answers. A PLS_INTEGER will be implicitly converted to a NUMBER and a BINARY_FLOAT
What is the difference between a and b?

comments.content: I think one of those should say NATURAL or NATURALN. And the answer is incorrect on this also.

questions.question_text:
Consider a function totalEmp () which takes a number as an input parameter and returns the total number of employees who have a salary higher than that parameter.

Examine this PL/SQL package AS -
//IMG//

Which two definitions of totalEmp () result in an implicit conversion by Oracle Database on executing this PL/SQL block?

choices.E: CREATE FUNCTION totalEmp (sal IN POSITIVEN) RETURN NUMBER IS total NUMBER :=0; BEGIN RETUNRN total; END;
choices.C: CREATE FUNCTION totalEmp (sal IN PLS_INTEGER) RETURN NUMBER IS total NUMBER :=0; BEGIN RETUNRN total; END; /
choices.D: CREATE FUNCTION totalEmp (sal IN BINARY_FLOAT) RETURN NUMBER IS total NUMBER :=0; BEGIN RETUNRN total; END; /
choices.B: CREATE FUNCTION totalEmp (sal IN NUMBER) RETURN NUMBER IS total NUMBER :=0; BEGIN RETUNRN total; END; /
choices.A: CREATE FUNCTION totalEmp (sal IN NUMBER) RETURN NUMBER IS total NUMBER :=0; BEGIN RETUNRN total; END; /

choices.B: When using DBMS_DATAPUMP, if SecureFiles LOB data needs to be encrypted then ENCRYPTION=ALL must be specified.
choices.C: If a BasicFiles LOB locator is passed to DBMS_LOB.ISSECUREFILE, an exception will be raised.
choices.D: An online redefinition of SecureFiles by DBMS_REDEFINIITON can be performed with PDML (Parallel DML).
choices.A: DBMS_LOB can be used to compress SecureFiles columns.

discussion.content: BD, not BC.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about PL/SQL AOIs for SecureFiles?
Which two can be used to find details of parameters for overloaded PL/SQL routines?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
Since the question asks specifically for information on parameters of procedures, B can't be right
all_procedures don't have any details about arguments. So answer is DE.

comments.content:
You are right, in all_procedures you have just an column called "overload" wich says if the procedure/function is overloade, but here I think it's about of syllabus of the question. They ask which 2 table can be used to know details about arguments (In my opinion they talked about using in the same time 2 tables, not separately). So you can know details of arguments using a join:
 SELECT a.* FROM all_arguments a, all_procedures p
 WHERE p.overload IS NOT NULL
 AND a.OBJECT_NAME = p.PROCEDURE_NAME
 ORDER BY p.PROCEDURE_NAME DESC, p.overload DESC;

discussion.content: B and E

B and E , both view includes overload column,
all_procedures, all_arguments
B and E
Confirm. DE is correct.

AE
A : successfully completed but some keyword should be in lower case
 DECLARE SUBTYPE new_one IS binary_integer range 0..9; my_val new_one; 
 BEGIN my_val :=0; dbms_output.put_line(my_val); END; 
B : PLS-00218: a variable declared NOT NULL must have an initialization assignment
C : ORA-06502: PL/SQL: numeric or value error: number precision too large
D : PLS-00218: a variable declared NOT NULL must have an initialization assignment
E : Correct

Selected Answer: AE
A : successfully completed but some keyword should be in lower case
DECLARE SUBTYPE new_one IS binary_integer range 0..9; my_val new_one;
BEGIN my_val :=0; dbms_output.put_line(my_val); END;
B : PLS-00218: a variable declared NOT NULL must have an initialization assignment
C : ORA-06502: PL/SQL: numeric or value error: number precision too large
D : PLS-00218: a variable declared NOT NULL must have an initialization assignment
E : Correct
AE is the correct answer

A,E are corrects
but in A you just have to write integer not interger, and in E just add the END keyword
AE are corrects , only E need "END" keyword

Correct Answer is AE not AD because subtype which is not null should be initialized
in D option.

questions.question_text: Which two blocks of code execute successfully?

choices.A: DECLARE SUBTYPE new_one IS BINARY_INTERGER RANGE 0..9; my_val new_one; BEGIN my_val :=0; END;
choices.E: DECLARE SUBTYPE new_one IS NUMBER (1, 0); my_val new_one; BEGIN my_val := -1;
choices.B: DECLARE SUBTYPE new_string IS VARCHAR2 (5) NOT NULL; my_str_new_string; BEGIN my_str := abc; END;
choices.C: DECLARE SUBTYPE new_one IS NUMBER (2, 1); my_val new_one; BEGIN my_val :=12.5; END;
choices.D: DECLARE SUBTYPE new_one IS INTEGER RANGE 1..10 NOT NULL; my_val new_one; BEGIN my_val :=2; END;
